title: Obama: Iran deal makes the world safer
content:
CLOSE President Obama touted progress made since the Iran nuclear deal , but said the U.S. would not ignore Iran 's `` destabilizing behavior elsewhere '' and its ballistic missile program . ███
WASHINGTON — President Obama said Sunday the United States , the region and the world will be more secure because of the just-completed nuclear deal with Iran .
`` This is a good day , because once again we 're seeing what 's possible with strong American diplomacy , '' Obama said .
`` Yesterday marked a milestone in preventing Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon , '' he said . `` Most important of all , we achieved this historic progress through diplomacy , without resorting to another war in the Middle East . ''
Obama 's remarks capped a 24-hour period that significantly reshaped U.S. relations with Iran . With the International Atomic Energy Agency certifying that Iran has complied with its agreement to scale back its nuclear program , Obama signed an executive order lifting nuclear-related sanctions .
In a side agreement , Iran released five Americans held captive , and Obama agreed to grant clemency to seven Iranians held in the United States . Obama called his use of the constitutional pardon power `` a one-time gesture to Iran , given the unique opportunity offered by this moment and the larger circumstances at play . ''
Obama also announced that the United States and Iran had settled a decades-long dispute regarding Iranian assets frozen during the 1979 Tehran hostage crisis . When Muslim students stormed the United States embassy in Tehran and took 66 hostages , President Carter froze $ 400 million in Iranian funds intended to buy military equipment .
That money is being returned with $ 1.3 billion in interest , settling claims at the Iran–United States Claims Tribunal in The Hague . U.S. citizens had already recovered $ 2.5 billion in claims against Iran through the same tribunal , the State Department said .
And earlier Sunday , the Treasury Department announced it was imposing sanctions on 11 people and companies involved in Iran 's ballistic missile program . `` We will continue to enforce these sanctions vigorously , '' Obama said . `` We are going to remain vigilant about it . ''
Obama had hoped to speak Saturday night , but waited until all the Americans — including Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian — were able to leave Tehran , senior administration officials said . Two officials , who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive details of the exchange , said two issues held up the plane ’ s departure : The crew needed enough rest before the long flight to Switzerland , and they wanted to make sure that Rezaian ’ s wife and mother were also on the plane .
Even as Obama spoke to reporters in the Cabinet Room of the White House , Republican candidates for president condemned the deal on Sunday morning television .
`` It reflects a pattern we ’ ve seen in the Obama administration over and over again of negotiating with terrorists , and making deals and trades that endanger U.S. safety and security , '' said Sen. Ted Cruz , R-Texas , on Fox News Sunday . `` Barack Obama is in the 'Let's-Make-A-Deal ' business . ''
content_original:
CLOSE President Obama touted progress made since the Iran nuclear deal, but said the U.S. would not ignore Iran's "destabilizing behavior elsewhere" and its ballistic missile program. USA TODAY

President Obama speaks about U.S.-Iranian relations, including the Iranian-American nationals that were jailed in Iran and are being freed as part of a prisoner swap, in the Cabinet Room of the White House Sunday. (Photo: Saul Loeb, AFP/Getty Images)

WASHINGTON — President Obama said Sunday the United States, the region and the world will be more secure because of the just-completed nuclear deal with Iran.

"This is a good day, because once again we're seeing what's possible with strong American diplomacy," Obama said.

"Yesterday marked a milestone in preventing Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon," he said. "Most important of all, we achieved this historic progress through diplomacy, without resorting to another war in the Middle East."

Obama's remarks capped a 24-hour period that significantly reshaped U.S. relations with Iran. With the International Atomic Energy Agency certifying that Iran has complied with its agreement to scale back its nuclear program, Obama signed an executive order lifting nuclear-related sanctions.

In a side agreement, Iran released five Americans held captive, and Obama agreed to grant clemency to seven Iranians held in the United States. Obama called his use of the constitutional pardon power "a one-time gesture to Iran, given the unique opportunity offered by this moment and the larger circumstances at play."

Obama also announced that the United States and Iran had settled a decades-long dispute regarding Iranian assets frozen during the 1979 Tehran hostage crisis. When Muslim students stormed the United States embassy in Tehran and took 66 hostages, President Carter froze $400 million in Iranian funds intended to buy military equipment.

That money is being returned with $1.3 billion in interest, settling claims at the Iran–United States Claims Tribunal in The Hague. U.S. citizens had already recovered $2.5 billion in claims against Iran through the same tribunal, the State Department said.

And earlier Sunday, the Treasury Department announced it was imposing sanctions on 11 people and companies involved in Iran's ballistic missile program. "We will continue to enforce these sanctions vigorously," Obama said. "We are going to remain vigilant about it."

Obama had hoped to speak Saturday night, but waited until all the Americans — including Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian — were able to leave Tehran, senior administration officials said. Two officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive details of the exchange, said two issues held up the plane’s departure: The crew needed enough rest before the long flight to Switzerland, and they wanted to make sure that Rezaian’s wife and mother were also on the plane.

Even as Obama spoke to reporters in the Cabinet Room of the White House, Republican candidates for president condemned the deal on Sunday morning television.

"It reflects a pattern we’ve seen in the Obama administration over and over again of negotiating with terrorists, and making deals and trades that endanger U.S. safety and security," said Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, on Fox News Sunday. "Barack Obama is in the 'Let's-Make-A-Deal' business."
